Summary: The proposal aims to bridge the gap between correlation and causation in neural networks by developing a hybrid framework that integrates differentiable causal discovery mechanisms into neural architectures. The framework includes three main components: differentiable causal discovery, causal-aware representation learning, and neural causal reasoning. The experiments are designed to validate the framework on synthetic and real-world datasets, with a focus on scalability and robustness to distribution shifts.
Strengths: Addresses a critical and timely problem in deep learning.
Proposes a novel and ambitious hybrid framework combining neural representation learning with causal graph inference.
Detailed and structured experiment plan with clear benchmarks and baselines.
Strong motivation and hypothesis grounded in existing literature.
Weaknesses: Lacks detailed discussion on how the latent causal graph learning module will scale to high-dimensional data.
Potential technical challenges in integrating differentiable causal discovery with neural networks are not fully addressed.
Limited discussion on potential pitfalls and mitigation strategies in the experiment plan.
The proposal could benefit from more concrete examples of how the framework will be applied to real-world high-dimensional data.
Questions: How will the latent causal graph learning module handle the curse of dimensionality in high-dimensional data?
What are the specific technical challenges in integrating differentiable causal discovery with neural networks, and how will they be addressed?
Can you provide more concrete examples of how the framework will be applied to real-world high-dimensional data like images or text?
What are the potential failure modes of the proposed invariance loss, and how will they be mitigated?
Limitations: Scalability of the latent causal graph learning module to high-dimensional data is uncertain.
Integration of differentiable causal discovery with neural networks may introduce computational overhead.
The proposed invariance loss may not generalize well to all types of distribution shifts.
